Physics laureate Gabriel Lippmann developed a revolutionary process for colour photographs. This process captured an interference pattern in a photosensitive emulsion when multiple light waves interact.
 
A glass plate was coated with light-sensitive film followed by pure mercury. When exposed, light rays struck the film and reflected back from the mercury.
 
The reflected waves interacted with the incoming and each other, causing interference patterns in the film. 
 
Once exposed, the plate was developed, fixed, and dried. The result was a vibrant colour photograph that didn‚Äôt fade.
